Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Decision Support System for Reasoning with Preferences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Automated decision support systems help users make informed and intelligent choices over a set of alternatives, taking into account user preferences and trade-offs among multiple system attributes. In the software engineering domain decision support systems are used to help in evaluating alternative design, technical and managerial choices in terms of quantitative preferences and trade-offs. Preferences over alternatives are evaluated either by directly soliciting from the stakeholders a measure of the perceived utility/value of each attribute, or by quantifying such utility/value based on past experience and expertise. In most practical settings, however, preferences over attributes cannot all be quantified. On the other hand, considering preferences only qualitatively (specifying them as simple relative orderings between alternatives) is also not practical. To overcome these limitations, the proposed research focuses on developing a new paradigm for decision support systems, where preferences are specified both in qualitative and quantitative terms.

The main thrust of this work will be to: (a) develop robust formalisms for representing and reasoning with quantitative and qualitative preferences in an unified fashion, (b) investigate application-domain specific extensions to the formalisms, and (c) identify implementation strategies for practical application of the decision support system as a preference analyzer. The anticipated results will help realize application-specific robust decision support systems in multiple domains, including product-line engineering, safety-critical system development, and goal-oriented requirements engineering, by enabling improved automated reasoning about preferences. This work will contribute to research-based training of a postdoctoral scholar and a graduate student in techniques that cut across software engineering, formal methods and artificial intelligence. Research results will be disseminated through publications in journals and conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAGER: Decision Support System for Reasoning with Preferences[http://fmg.cs.iastate.edu/project-pages/preference-reasoner/]

Problems in many application domains call for techniques forrepresenting and reasoning with preferences. For instance, indesigning a house, the owners and the contractors may have differentset of (possibly conflicting) preferences over the cost and/or thetype of materials to be used in the construction. The objective is toidentify a solution that is most preferred (or optimal) and thatsatisfies certain important regulations (for example, regulations ofthe city/town and the engineers). Similar optimal design problems arealso important in software engineering, where software with specificfunctionalities are developed based on the preferences of theend-users (who may have preferences over usability features), thedevelopers (who may have preferences over development methods) and themanagers (who may have preferences over the cost of development).  Inall these scenarios, the stake-holders describing the preferences arehuman subjects and often their preferences are not quantifiable(measurable in a simple number scale).  For instance, customersatisfaction or preference of a color over another are properties thatare not quantifiable. As a result, it becomes important to considerpreferences as they are, i.e., qualitative, and not to imposeartificial numbers to quantify the degree of preference of onealternate over another. In fact, several scientific studies haverevealed that artificial quantification provides a false perception ofaccuracy and result in decisions which are counter to thestake-holders' preferences. The central theme of our research isaddress the problem of reasoning with preferences in qualitative termsand investigate the use our reasoning methodology in differentapplication domains.

Key Knowledge Gaps 

We primarily address two challenges in qualitative preferencereasoning. First, we develop techniques based on formal methods forreasoning with preference that guarantees the correctness of thereasoner (i.e., always identifies the preferred results). Second, ourtechnique also provides justification of the computed results; thejustification is based on the preferences purely in qualitative termsand does not rely on any perceived or computed quantification of thedegree of preferences.

Project Findings

We have developed a new technique for reasoning with preferences inqualitative terms that is general. Therefore, it is applied to reasonwith preferences expressed in different types of preferencelanguages. A tool, iPref-R, with an intuitive and an easy-to-usegraphical user interface is developed based on the technique.

Benefit to Science of Computing

A general framework for reasoning with different types of preferenceswith different expressive power has been developed. The correctness ofthe framework and justifiability of the computed results have beenproved. The results of the project not only advance the state-of-artin qualitative preference reasoning but also broaden the scope ofapplication of Software Engineering and Formal Methods techniques suchas model checking, which forms one of the key components in ourpreference reasoning framework. 

Contributions to Learning and Work-Force Development

One post-doctoral researcher and one doctoral student have beendirectly involved in the project.
